verses.text: This is what the Lord GOD showed me: Behold, a basket of summer fruit.
verses.comment: The vision of ripe fruit symbolizes the nearness of Israel’s judgment—like fruit ready to be harvested. The original Hebrew puns on the word for 'summer fruit' and 'end.' See also Jeremiah’s visions for similar prophetic symbolism.

verses.text: And He said, 'Amos, what do you see?' And I said, 'A basket of summer fruit.' Then the LORD said to me, 'The end has come upon My people Israel; I will not spare them any longer.'
verses.comment: God’s patience has limits—Israel’s sins reach their fullness, echoing themes in the prophets of coming judgment. The wordplay connects the ripeness of fruit with the nearness of ending.

verses.text: 'The songs of the temple shall become wailing in that day,' declares the Lord GOD. 'The dead bodies shall be many; in every place they shall be thrown out in silence.'
verses.comment: The reversal from songs to wailing shows the totality of coming judgment. The silence echoes ancient lament traditions, with the removal of liturgy as a sign of God’s displeasure. Liturgical worship’s seriousness is reinforced (see Revelation 8:1 for a time of silence in heaven).

verses.text: Hear this, you who trample the needy and do away with the poor of the land,
verses.comment: God's judgment especially targets injustice and oppression—a consistent biblical theme. Compare Jesus' teaching on the poor (Luke 4:18; Matthew 25:40), showing this concern extends into the new covenant.

verses.text: saying, 'When will the New Moon be over, that we may sell grain? And the Sabbath, that we may offer wheat for sale, making the ephah small and the shekel large, and cheating with dishonest scales,
verses.comment: Observance of religious festivals is shown to be hollow when not joined to justice. The technical references to New Moon/Sabbath highlight ritual law, yet hearts remain unchanged. Compare with Isaiah 1:13 and Jesus' critique of hypocrisy in worship (Mark 7:6-7).

verses.text: so that we may buy the poor for silver and the needy for a pair of sandals, and sell even the chaff of the wheat.'
verses.comment: Economic injustice becomes slavery; the poorest suffer exploitation (see Leviticus 25:39's law to protect debtors). Such sins show the call for faith and works together. See James 2:15-17 for New Testament resonance.

verses.text: The LORD has sworn by the pride of Jacob: 'Surely, I will never forget any of their deeds.'
verses.comment: God’s oath underlines the seriousness of the coming punishment. His memory contrasts with forgetfulness; ultimate justice is guaranteed. References to ‘pride of Jacob’ may mean either their national glory or God Himself.

verses.text: Shall not the land tremble on this account, and everyone who dwells in it mourn? All of it shall rise like the Nile, be tossed about and sink again, like the Nile of Egypt.'
verses.comment: Judgment will shake the land itself—God’s discipline is cosmic, affecting even creation. The imagery of the Nile’s flooding communicates upheaval and disaster (cf. Amos 9:5).

verses.text: 'And in that day,' declares the Lord GOD, 'I will make the sun go down at noon and darken the earth in broad daylight.'
verses.comment: This prophecy (darkness at midday) symbolizes divine judgment and echoes the Exodus plagues. Ultimately, it prefigures the darkness at Jesus’ crucifixion (see Matthew 27:45), deepening its christological significance.

verses.text: 'I will turn your feasts into mourning and all your songs into lamentation; I will bring sackcloth on every waist and baldness on every head. I will make it like the mourning for an only son, and the end of it like a bitter day.'
verses.comment: Judgment will strike at the center of community and family life. The image of mourning for an only son points ahead to the grief over Christ, the Only Son (see Zechariah 12:10, fulfilled in John 19:37).

verses.text: 'Behold, the days are coming,' declares the Lord GOD, 'when I will send a famine on the land—not a famine of bread, nor a thirst for water, but of hearing the words of the LORD.'
verses.comment: Spiritual famine is deadlier than physical hunger—divine silence is a fearful judgment. The necessity of God's word anticipates Christ as the living Word (John 1:1; Matthew 4:4).

verses.text: People shall wander from sea to sea, and from the north to the east; they shall run to and fro to seek the word of the LORD, but they shall not find it.
verses.comment: The desperate search for a prophet or divine revelation, yet God’s silence is total. This drives home the value of authentic revelation and guidance through apostolic succession (cf. Acts 8:31—‘How can I, unless someone guides me?’).

verses.text: In that day the beautiful young women and the strong young men shall faint for thirst.
verses.comment: Physical vigor cannot save against God’s judgment; all are vulnerable. Thirst here has both literal and spiritual implication, pointing to humanity’s need for the grace that satisfies (cf. John 4:13–14; Christ, the source of living water).

verses.text: Those who swear by the guilt of Samaria, and say, 'As your god lives, O Dan,' or, 'As the way of Beersheba lives,' they shall fall and never rise again.'
verses.comment: Idolatry leads to downfall; false worship—even if sincere—cannot save. The mention of Dan and Beersheba refers to rival sanctuaries. The call is to persevere in fidelity to true revealed worship.
